body_html:
Follow what the C API does. To me this sounds like there's a bug in the java swig code somewhere which is confusing enums and string dtype names.
…
On Fri, Aug 18, 2017 at 8:35 AM, Anthony Platanios ***@***.*** > wrote: @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> Sounds good! I'll try to get those changes in today. One question I have related to this is whether to use tf_cuda_library and tf_cc_test, instead of cc_library and cc_test, as is done for the C API. What do you think? Regarding the attribute name, I'll try to get some code that reproduces it in C++ so you can test. One thing I've noticed is that so far it only happens with attributes that have data types as values. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. -- - Alex

Follow what the C API does.

To me this sounds like there's a bug in the java swig code somewhere which
is confusing enums and string dtype names.

 @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> Sounds good! I'll try to get those
 changes in today. One question I have related to this is whether to use
 tf_cuda_library and tf_cc_test, instead of cc_library and cc_test, as is
 done for the C API. What do you think?

 Regarding the attribute name, I'll try to get some code that reproduces it
 in C++ so you can test. One thing I've noticed is that so far it only
 happens with attributes that have data types as values.

body:
Follow what the C API does.

To me this sounds like there's a bug in the java swig code somewhere which
is confusing enums and string dtype names.

On Fri, Aug 18, 2017 at 8:35 AM, Anthony Platanios <notifications@github.com
> wrote:

> @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> Sounds good! I'll try to get those
> changes in today. One question I have related to this is whether to use
> tf_cuda_library and tf_cc_test, instead of cc_library and cc_test, as is
> done for the C API. What do you think?
>
> Regarding the attribute name, I'll try to get some code that reproduces it
> in C++ so you can test. One thing I've noticed is that so far it only
> happens with attributes that have data types as values.
>
> —
